Wow. All I have to say is: even Frank S. says that interpretation is everything, even Mark Macy says that.  It's the subjective element that's tormented parapsychology since it began.  But it's that same element that's kept it going.
  As an author of books on ghosts and hauntings, I've had a thousand people in twenty years give me photos of ghosts that I can't see.  Never once have I said, "These people are crazy."
  Every time I've said: Is there something that I'm lacking that makes me not see?"
  Deep down I've known that so many must be the photos of wishful thinkers, but in order to make this stuff go, you have to just open it all up.  Otherwise, we are as bad as the rest.
  Just open it up.  We have to open it so wide in the other direction of the crassly skeptical.
  Somewhere, there will be a middle ground where we find the truth. 
  Anyway, that's my feeling.  Mark Macy says, and I'm NOT quoting , "When I encounter unbelievable claims, I look at the character of the claimants.  If I trust them, I trust the claims.  That's the best I can do." 
  That's what I do with you guys.  I see your work.  I see your love.  I believe you.  When you tell me "Listen for . . . " I listen for the words you say the spirits have said.
  It's not the traditionally scientific thing to do, but this phenomena has eluded verification and classification by traditional science for generations.
   
  Ursula
   
  

Lisby <lisby@...> wrote: 
          I think there is a huge difference between the evidence obtained by EVP research and the Luminator pictures.  When you have a clear answer to a question that is captured in realtime, with witness potential and in a format that can be analyzed afterward, you have a heck of a lot of more leg to stand on, HMO.   

  I have tried telling people who claim their loved ones appeared in a Luminator picture, and I got exactly the emotive response I suppose I deserved for trying. You can reason with a broken heart, and that's what a lot of people have when they are photographed. I once attended a seance where a supposed medium held a flashlight up to his face at different angles in a dark room and claimed that viewers would see their relatives and other spirits manifest themselves over his face. And they did. A whole room of them shouted out that it was their relative or Abraham Lincoln, or whatever. Those of us who saw a guy in a dark room making faces with a spooky light on his face were told in no uncertain terms that we were skeptics and debunkers or that we didn't see the faces because we weren't rarified enough to do so.
  

  As for the three Luminators allowing the guy's head to pass through the wall... Well, I'd have to see it, or better yet, personally experience it, to believe it myself.
  

  As always, your milage may vary,
  

  Ann
  

  

      On Dec 29, 2007, at 4:05 PM, Ursula Bielski wrote:

          

  Hi, guys--
  Glad to see everyone talking about the Luminator.  Absolutely the Luminator was not made for what Mark does with it, and he will be the first to tell you that.  The thing about it is: it's the same as what we do: if you're a total skeptic you can say: the results are wishful thinking.  But try telling that to those who've seen their loved ones in the Luminator photos
  There's some other cool stuff:  for all you Philadelphia Experiment folks, Mark writes about his buddy who had three Luminoators set up in his office at one time, leaned his head against the wall, and had his head go through the wall.  There's just something very physical going on--no games, no whatever--make what you like of it, bottom line is: it's got us talking, right?
  Happy New year, all,
  Urs
